title: Lens of the Still Sky
quest_giver: Lysa Quill (for the Night Cartographers), warned by Sula Reedmantle
description: The Glasslake of Sere lies like a pupil that never dilates. The ruined observatory clings to its promontory, brasswork melted long ago by a heat that had a moral. The Night Cartographers, through Lysa Quill’s careful smile, offer Kezra a trade: recover a lens said to cut reflections from water like cloth, and they will deliver a map that dodges the reed-thing’s hunting grounds. Sula warns that such cuts leave scars in the mirror and the mind. The lake shows futures if stared at too long; the reeds on the shore gossip in breeze-voices about who drowned where. Kezra must decide who deserves the lens’s custody, and whether any price is fair when futures are currency.
objectives: Travel to the Glasslake of Sere and explore the observatory ruins safely, avoiding razorweed and star-sickness.
Recover the reflection-cutting lens without gazing too long into still water.
Decide whether to deliver the lens to the Night Cartographers, the Lantern Archive, or to keep it under Order seal.
Resist a tempting ‘future’ shown by the lake; leave with mind and purpose intact.

dialogue.speaker: Lysa Quill
dialogue.lines: A map is a mercy when it spares you mistakes you’ve seen others make. The lens will let you take a reflection and study it until the truth stands up and introduces itself. Give it to us, and we’ll give you a path out of your city’s future that tastes like a lie you won’t have to tell.

dialogue.speaker: Sula Reedmantle
dialogue.lines: The lake keeps favors like a jealous lover. If you must take the lens, you must promise to return its power to a house that values memory over leverage. The Cartographers value prices, and prices are the fastest way to turn a truth into a tool.

dialogue.speaker: A Fisher of Sere
dialogue.lines: Keep your breath shallow and your eyes on your oars. The lake shows you a version of yourself who always says yes. Real people sometimes say no. Remember that while you’re carrying glass that wants to be a knife.

dialogue.speaker: Kezra Thorneglass
dialogue.lines: I’ve cut a reflection once and paid in night sweats for it. I’ll take the lens out of this place, but I won’t let it turn me into a knife someone else can hold. If I must choose a custodian, I’ll choose the one least likely to sell my city to its own reflection.

rewards: Reflection-cutting lens secured under agreed custody (tool for final rite)
A partial ‘mirror map’ from the Night Cartographers or, if refused, a coded warning about reed-thing tides
A calm-breath exercise learned from the fishers (resists panic in vision-heavy scenes)
